attribute.name: CLAUDE.md Configuration Files
attribute.description: Project-specific configuration for Claude Code
attribute.criteria: CLAUDE.md file exists in repository root

attribute.name: README Structure
attribute.description: Well-structured README with key sections
attribute.criteria: README.md with installation, usage, and development sections

attribute.name: Type Annotations
attribute.description: Type hints in function signatures
attribute.criteria: >80% of functions have type annotations

remediation.summary: Add type annotations to function signatures
steps: For Python: Add type hints to function parameters and return types
For TypeScript: Enable strict mode in tsconfig.json
Use mypy or pyright for Python type checking
Use tsc --strict for TypeScript
Add type annotations gradually to existing code

attribute.name: Standard Project Layouts
attribute.description: Follows standard project structure for language
attribute.criteria: Standard directories (src/, tests/, docs/) present

attribute.name: Dependency Pinning for Reproducibility
attribute.description: Dependencies pinned to exact versions in lock files
attribute.criteria: Lock file with pinned versions, updated within 6 months

findings.threshold: lock file with pinned versions, < 6 months old

attribute.name: Dependency Security & Vulnerability Scanning
attribute.description: Security scanning tools configured for dependencies and code
attribute.criteria: Dependabot, CodeQL, or SAST tools configured; secret detection enabled

remediation.summary: Add more security scanning tools for comprehensive coverage
steps: Enable Dependabot alerts in GitHub repository settings
Add CodeQL scanning workflow for SAST
Configure secret detection (detect-secrets, gitleaks)
Set up language-specific scanners (pip-audit, npm audit, Snyk)
commands: pip install detect-secrets  # Python secret detection
examples:
# .github/dependabot.yml
version: 2
updates:
  - package-ecosystem: pip
    directory: /
    schedule:
      interval: weekly

citations.title: Dependency-Check Project
citations.relevance: Open-source tool for detecting known vulnerabilities in dependencies

citations.title: Dependabot Documentation
citations.relevance: Official guide for configuring automated dependency updates and security alerts

attribute.name: Test Coverage Requirements
attribute.description: Test coverage thresholds configured and enforced
attribute.criteria: >80% code coverage

attribute.name: Pre-commit Hooks & CI/CD Linting
attribute.description: Pre-commit hooks configured for linting and formatting
attribute.criteria: .pre-commit-config.yaml exists

attribute.name: Conventional Commit Messages
attribute.description: Follows conventional commit format
attribute.criteria: ≥80% of recent commits follow convention

steps: Install commitlint
Configure husky for commit-msg hook

attribute.name: .gitignore Completeness
attribute.description: Comprehensive .gitignore file with language-specific patterns
attribute.criteria: .gitignore exists and includes language-specific patterns from GitHub templates

attribute.name: One-Command Build/Setup
attribute.description: Single command to set up development environment from fresh clone
attribute.criteria: Single command (make setup, npm install, etc.) documented prominently

evidence: Setup command found in README: 'pip install'

attribute.name: File Size Limits
attribute.description: Files are reasonably sized for AI context windows
attribute.criteria: <5% of files >500 lines, no files >1000 lines

remediation.summary: Refactor large files into smaller, focused modules
steps: Identify files >1000 lines
Split into logical submodules
Extract classes/functions into separate files
Maintain single responsibility principle
examples:
# Split large file:
# models.py (1500 lines) → models/user.py, models/product.py, models/order.py

attribute.name: Separation of Concerns
attribute.description: Code organized with single responsibility per module
attribute.criteria: Feature-based organization, cohesive modules, low coupling

attribute.name: Concise Documentation
attribute.description: Documentation maximizes information density while minimizing token consumption
attribute.criteria: README <500 lines with clear structure, bullet points over prose

remediation.summary: Make documentation more concise and structured
steps: Break long README into multiple documents (docs/ directory)
Add clear Markdown headings (##, ###) for structure
Convert prose paragraphs to bullet points where possible
Add table of contents for documents >100 lines
Use code blocks instead of describing commands in prose
Move detailed content to wiki or docs/, keep README focused
examples:
# Good: Concise with structure

## Quick Start
```bash
pip install -e .
agentready assess .
```

## Features
- Fast repository scanning
- HTML and Markdown reports
- 25 agent-ready attributes

## Documentation
See [docs/](docs/) for detailed guides.
# Bad: Verbose prose

This project is a tool that helps you assess your repository
against best practices for AI-assisted development. It works by
scanning your codebase and checking for various attributes that
make repositories more effective when working with AI coding
assistants like Claude Code...

[Many more paragraphs of prose...]

citations.title: LongCodeBench: Evaluating Coding LLMs at 1M Context Windows
citations.relevance: Research showing performance degradation with long contexts

attribute.name: Inline Documentation
attribute.description: Function, class, and module-level documentation using language-specific conventions
attribute.criteria: ≥80% of public functions/classes have docstrings

attribute.name: Cyclomatic Complexity Thresholds
attribute.description: Cyclomatic complexity thresholds enforced
attribute.criteria: Average complexity <10, no functions >15

attribute.name: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)
attribute.description: Lightweight documents capturing architectural decisions
attribute.criteria: ADR directory with documented decisions

evidence: No ADR directory found (checked docs/adr/, .adr/, adr/, docs/decisions/)

remediation.summary: Create Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) directory and document key decisions
steps: Create docs/adr/ directory in repository root
Use Michael Nygard ADR template or MADR format
Document each significant architectural decision
Number ADRs sequentially (0001-*.md, 0002-*.md)
Include Status, Context, Decision, and Consequences sections
Update ADR status when decisions are revised (Superseded, Deprecated)
commands: We need to record architectural decisions made in this project.
We will use Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) as described by Michael Nygard.
examples:
# Example ADR Structure

```markdown
# 2. Use PostgreSQL for Database

Date: 2025-11-22

## Status
Accepted

## Context
We need a relational database for complex queries and ACID transactions.
Team has PostgreSQL experience. Need full-text search capabilities.

## Decision
Use PostgreSQL 15+ as primary database.

## Consequences
- Positive: Robust ACID, full-text search, team familiarity
- Negative: Higher resource usage than SQLite
- Neutral: Need to manage migrations, backups
```

attribute.name: Issue & Pull Request Templates
attribute.description: Standardized templates for issues and PRs
attribute.criteria: PR template and issue templates in .github/

attribute.name: CI/CD Pipeline Visibility
attribute.description: Clear, well-documented CI/CD configuration files
attribute.criteria: CI config with descriptive names, caching, parallelization

attribute.name: Semantic Naming
attribute.description: Systematic naming patterns following language conventions
attribute.criteria: Language conventions followed, avoid generic names

evidence: No generic names (temp, data, obj) detected

attribute.name: Structured Logging
attribute.description: Logging in structured format (JSON) with consistent fields
attribute.criteria: Structured logging library configured (structlog, winston, zap)

remediation.summary: Add structured logging library for machine-parseable logs
steps: Choose structured logging library (structlog for Python, winston for Node.js)
Install library and configure JSON formatter
Add standard fields: timestamp, level, message, context
Include request context: request_id, user_id, session_id
Use consistent field naming (snake_case for Python)
Never log sensitive data (passwords, tokens, PII)
Configure different formats for dev (pretty) and prod (JSON)
examples:
# Python with structlog
import structlog

# Configure structlog
structlog.configure(
    processors=[
        structlog.stdlib.add_log_level,
        structlog.processors.TimeStamper(fmt="iso"),
        structlog.processors.JSONRenderer()
    ]
)

logger = structlog.get_logger()

# Good: Structured logging
logger.info(
    "user_login",
    user_id="123",
    email="user@example.com",
    ip_address="192.168.1.1"
)

# Bad: Unstructured logging
logger.info(f"User {user_id} logged in from {ip}")

attribute.name: OpenAPI/Swagger Specifications

attribute.criteria: OpenAPI 3.x spec with complete endpoint documentation
